subject: Medicine
title: Conflicts of Interest
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Conflicts of Interest.

hook.text: Pharmaceutical companies spent $20 billion marketing directly to US doctors in one year. That buys influence.

buildup.text: Conflicts of interest arise when personal gain could compromise a doctor's objectivity in patient care.

discovery.text: Drug company gifts, speaking fees, and research funding can subtly bias prescribing and treatment decisions.

twist.text: Studies show even small giftsâ€”a free lunchâ€”shift prescribing habits toward the sponsoring company's drugs.

climax.text: Transparency laws now require disclosure, but eliminating bias requires constant vigilance and systemic change.

punchline.text: When money enters medicine, patients must ask who benefits.

quiz.question: How do small gifts from drug companies affect doctors?
options: They subtly shift prescribing habits toward that company's drugs
They have no measurable effect on medical decisions
They only influence doctors who accept gifts over $1,000
